citations.narrative:
The facility is not currently following their Program of Vet Care (PVC). Of the 18 adult dogs, 12 are not current on the 3
required vaccinations: rabies, distemper, and parvovirus. The PVC currently prescribes for these vaccinations to be given
yearly.
- Female Bernese Mountain Dog, Brandy (#0604) last had a rabies vaccination on 10/3/22. It is currently due.
- Male Frenchie, Sarge (#9917) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations. All
are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Honey Blue Chip (#387060) last had a rabies vaccination on 10/3/22. It is currently due.
- Female black/tan Frenchie (unnamed) #6817 has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus
vaccinations. All are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Samamtha (#3643) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus
vaccinations. All are now due.
- Female Frenchie, FiFi (#2391) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations. All
are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Diamond (#3639) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations.
All are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Goldie (#3642) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations. All
are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Kendra (#3640) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations.
All are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Tina (#8077) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus vaccinations. All
are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Isabella Fluffy (#8071) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus
vaccinations. All are now due.
- Female Frenchie, Isabella Tan (#8065) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus
vaccinations. All are now due.
Rabies is a deadly virus which causes neurological symptoms and death. It can be passed from dogs to humans through
a bite wound. Distemper and parvovirus are very contagious diseases of dogs. They can cause vomiting, diarrhea,
neurological symptoms, anorexia, lethargy, dehydration, and death. Vaccination is an important component of preventing
these deadly diseases. Additionally, mothers will pass immunity gained by vaccinations to their offspring through their
milk.
Additionally, the facility has not been performing screening testing for fecal samples as prescribed in the PVC. The PVC
calls for 10% of adults and 10% of puppies to have fecal samples tested. In the past year, the facility has had one puppy
fecal sample tested. Routine screening of fecal samples is important for surveillance testing for intestinal parasites.
Intestinal parasites can cause diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, and other symptoms.
The facility must comply, in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian, for completion of
vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus) and sampling
and treatment of parasites (including worms, coccidia, and giardia). Correct by January 1, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not currently following their Program of Vet Care (PVC). Of the 18 adult dogs, 12 are not current on the 3 
required vaccinations: rabies, distemper, and parvovirus.  The PVC currently prescribes for these vaccinations to be given 
yearly. 
 
-  Female Bernese Mountain Dog, Brandy (#0604) last had a rabies vaccination on 10/3/22. It is currently due.  
-  Male Frenchie, Sarge (#9917) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus  vaccinations. All 
are now due.  
-  Female Frenchie, Honey Blue Chip (#387060)  last had a rabies vaccination on 10/3/22. It is currently due.  
-  Female black/tan Frenchie (unnamed) #6817 has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus

vaccinations. All are now due.  
-  Female Frenchie, Isabella Tan (#8065) has no record of receiving the rabies and distemper/parvovirus 
vaccinations. All are now due.  
 
Rabies is a deadly virus which causes neurological symptoms and death. It can be passed from dogs to humans through 
a bite wound. Distemper and parvovirus  are very contagious diseases of dogs. They can cause vomiting, diarrhea,

neurological symptoms, anorexia, lethargy, dehydration, and death. Vaccination is an important component of preventing

Additionally, the facility has not been performing screening testing for fecal samples as prescribed in the PVC. The PVC

fecal sample tested. Routine screening of fecal samples is important for surveillance testing for intestinal parasites. 
Intestinal parasites can cause diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, and other symptoms.  
 
The facility must comply, in accordance with a schedule approved  by the Attending Veterinarian, for completion of 
vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs (including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus)  and sampling 
and treatment of parasites (including worms, coccidia, and giardia). Correct by January 1, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
